page.title: 03Younger Dunes; Murlough
page.content: These are thought to date back to about the 13th or 14th Century. They are high (30m to 40m) and steeper than the older ones. They form a main dune ridge down the centre of the Reserve with an active foredune ridge (12m to 15m high) to the seaward side. These dunes are less stable than the older ones inland. Typical vegetation includes Marram Grass, Sea Buckthorn, Thistles, Sea Spurge, Fescues, Violas, Thyme, Scabious, Storksbill, Plantains, Scarlet Pimpernel and various fungi, lichens and mosses. Shingle flats produced by wind erosion of the overlying sand are often lichen covered with Stonecrop and Portland Spurge. Some of the lichens become large (e.g. Dog lichen over 30cm in diameter). Because of the leaching of the soil, acidity increases inland and more heathland species appear.
